Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Uncovering molecular mechanisms of facial recognition using comparative transcriptomics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Very few animals, mostly humans and other primates, are known to have a special ability to recognize each other's faces. How is this impressive feat of learning accomplished? Until now, technical limitations have made it difficult to study the ways in which animals' brains and genes permit them to recognize faces. Here the researchers are taking advantage of what some may consider a surprising model for this, insects, to delve into how facial recognition works on the level of brains and genes. The researchers have shown that several species of social paper wasps (Polistes) possess the ability to recognize individual faces. Polistes fuscatus wasps have striking variation in facial color patterns and they can learn faces much more readily than other visual patterns. In contrast a closely related species, Polistes metricus, does not have facial variation and lacks the special ability to learn faces more readily than other patterns. These two species with contrasting facial recognition abilities provide a unique opportunity to study the relationship between genes, brains and this ability. In collaboration with Dr. Elizabeth Tibbetts, wasps of each species are trained to recognize faces or non-face patterns. Dr. Toth and Ms. Berens will use "next generation" sequencing to measure the activity of thousands of genes in these wasps' brains to determine whether there are particular genes associated with facial recognition. The team will then manipulate gene activity in wasps' brains in order to determine whether such a change can improve or impair wasps' facial recognition abilities. Understanding the interplay between brains, genes, and facial recognition will be of benefit to human health since disordered facial recognition can impair human social interactions. This project is significant because it will use the paper wasp model to provide the first in-depth genetic analysis of a sophisticated form of learning that has been difficult to study in detail in humans and other primates.

RNA data will be deposited at ArrayExpress (http://www.ebi.ac.uk/arrayexpress/)

POR.DRECONTENT:
Individual facial recognition is important for appropriate social interactions in some animal species, including humans, macaques, and sheep. How is this specialized form of memory accomplished? So far, little is known about the underlying mechanisms controlling facial recognition. Most work on facial recognition in vertebrates has been limited to measuring brain region activity, but misses any genetic component. Social paper wasps in the genus Polistes are the only known insect to possess individual facial recognition. These wasps offer a more experimentally tractable model compared to vertebrate models for mechanistic analysis of the underlying genetics of this complex behavior. The overall goal of this project was to understand how wasps are able to recall individual's faces by looking at which genes are being expressed in the brains of two closely related species of wasps – P. fuscatus (has the ability to recognize faces) and P. metricus (does not).

From staged social encounters between pairs of wasps for each species, PI Toth and student Berens identified changes in genes related to calcium signaling, a common type of signaling between neurons in the brain, during memory recall of individual's identities. Using the pharmacological agent lithium chloride to disrupt calcium signaling in the brain, treated wasps compared to controls were able to extend the length of time that they were able to recognize individuals. This part of the project allowed us to identify a new possible mechanism for individual recognition in paper wasps.

To home in on face specific recognition, collaborator Elizabeth Tibbetts from the University of Michigan trained wasps from both species to learn either simple black and white patterns or wasp faces. Using cutting-edge next generation sequencing technology, PI Toth and student Berens observed a global 'snapshot' of genes expressed in the brain during pattern and face training. Comparing these snapshots between training types revealed only a small number of differences, none of which are shared between both species. In the wasp species with facial recognition (P. fuscatus), some of the genes that differ between training groups are also known to function in olfactory recognition in other insects. This suggests that some of the same genes may be involved in two different recognition systems. 

 

In the realm of broader impacts, this project provided excellent training opportunities for graduate student Ali Berens, who has graduated with her PhD in bioinformatics and moved on to a postdoctoral position. Berens also trained and worked with two undergraduates, providing them with research opportunities in animal behavior and bioinformatics.  Berens also participated in several publication and educational outreach events to disseminate information related to this project to the general public.  First, she developed a public outreach demonstration on wasp vs. human facial recognition. Like the game ‘Memory’, the demonstration asks participates to remember human faces, wasp faces, or generic patterns and flip matching cards. This demonstration has been presented at the Science Center of Iowa and as part of PollinatorFest hosted by Reiman Gardens at Iowa State University.
